titlestmt.title: The Book of Thel Copy N : electronic edition
titlestmt.sponsor: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, the University of Rochester, and the Library of Congress

filedesc.extent: XML file derived from 1 SGML (ISO 8879) encoded file approx. 117KB; 16 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 198KB to 1400KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; UNC Libraries July 2014
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of The Book of Thel copy N and Enoch Walked with God, both in the Cincinnati Art Museum. We have also republished Songs of Innocence copy U with a more authoritative arrangement of the plates and an enhanced Copy Information page.
Thel is dated 1789 by Blake on the title page, but the first plate (Thel's Motto) and the last (her descent into the netherworld) appear to have been completed and first printed in 1790, while Blake was working on The Marriage of Heaven and Hell. Copy N, never before reproduced, was printed and colored c. 1818 along with copy O. It is one of sixteen extant copies, ten of which are in the Blake Archive—including copy O—and four of which are in preparation for future publication. Like copy O, copy N was printed in orange ink on Ruse & Turners paper, watermarked 1815, beautifully colored, numbered by Blake in pen and ink, and bound with Thel's Motto as the last instead of the first of the book's eight plates. Unlike copy O, its plates have a single orange line framing them.
Blake included the book in his advertisement "To the Public" of October 1793: "The Book of Thel, a Poem in Illuminated Printing. Quarto, with 6 designs, price 3s." He listed it again in 1818, in a letter to Dawson Turner, in which he priced it for £2.2.0., the price for which copy N almost certainly sold. This letter is also in preparation for future publication.
Enoch Walked with God, at 17.5 x 24 inches, is one of Blake's largest early designs. It was executed c. 1780-85 in water colors and pen and ink over pencil and charcoal. It joins sixty-four other water color drawings in the Archive illustrating the Bible.
This is the first time that works from the Cincinnati Art Museum have been represented in the Archive. Accordingly, we are also publishing the museum's Blake collection list, which includes all of its original works by Blake, not just those published in the Archive, and joins the Collection Lists of over thirty other contributing institutions.
Additionally, with this publication, the Archive has implemented a new feature on its main viewing page to enable users to rotate the image, a particularly salient feature for Blake's texts written upside down or vertically.
The Archive has also updated its General and Specific Bibliographies, which now incorporate links to many Google Books.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, colorist
objdescid.compdate: 1789Objects 7 and 8 (Bentley plates 8 and 1) may have been composed at a slightly later date (late 1789 or early 1790) than the others. These same two plates were probably etched later than the others (late 1789 or early 1790).

objinfo.objorder: Bentley plates 2-8, 1The placement of "Thel's Motto" (Bentley plate 1) at the end of this copy is authorized by Blake's pen and ink number, "8," inscribed on it. This is also true of copy O, like copy N printed in 1818.
objinfo.objsize: Objects 1-7, approx. 15.0 x 11.0 cm.; object 8, 6.1 x 10.1 cm.
objinfo.medium: relief etching with hand coloring in water colors
objinfo.watermark: RUSE & TURNERS/1815The watermark appears only in the leaves bearing objects 5 and 7 (Bentley plates 6 and 8).
objinfo.etchednumbers: Blake etched numbers 1-6 on the copperplates of objects 2-7 (Bentley plates 3-8). Only those on objects 3, 4, 6, and 7 are even minimally legible in this copy.
objinfo.pennednumbers: Object 2 is numbered "2" top right, and objects 6-8 are numbered 6-8 top right, in ink that matches the color of the printing ink.The pen and ink numbers were probably intended to supersede the etched numbers, but Blake did not complete the numbering of all plates, there being no pen and ink numbers on objects 3 through 5. The pencil numbers, 3-5 top right on objects 3-5, are almost certainly not by Blake. They may have been added by a binder who collated the plates and supplied the missing numbers.
objinfo.framelines: 1Some plates have a pen and ink outline drawn at the edges of the images.
objinfo.binding: red morocco by RiviereThis binding was created after the sale of the book in 1890. At that sale, this copy of *The Book of Thel* was bound in calf with *The Marriage of Heaven and Hell* Copy G and *Visions of the Daughters of Albion* Copy P.

provenance.name: Cincinnati Art Museum
provenance.note: Sold, when bound with *The Marriage of Heaven and Hell* Copy G and *Visions of the Daughters of Albion* Copy P, Sotheby's, 17 Feb. 1890, lot 301 (£121 to "Robson," probably the dealer Robson & Kerslake); offered by Robson & Kerslake to Alexander Mackay in a letter of 25 March 1890 (see Bentley page 129); Mackay's wife, probably by inheritance; sold from the estate of Mrs. Alexander Mackay, Christie's, 26 April 1921, lot 1 (£205 to "Shoebridge," probably a code name for a dealer); John J. Emery no later than 1939; given by Emery to the Cincinnati Art Museum in 1969.

desc.objtitle: THE BOOK of THEL, object 1 (Bentley 2, Erdman ii, Keynes ii)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A slender tree, entwined with a vine, arches protectively over the title words and major pictorial motifs. This combination of motifs and their position suggests a tombstone. Four birds and a human figure soar in the sky; seven other human forms, one winged, rest or climb among the title letters. Thel, wearing a long gown and holding a shepherd's crook, stands lower left and gazes at a nude man embracing a gowned woman around her waist. The gowned woman raises her arms. These figures seem to emerge from the large, bowl-like flowers lower center and right. The leaves of this plant and a flower bud complete the design lower center and right. The design does not directly illustrate a scene in the text, but the figures embracing above the flowers may suggest the "raptures" (object 4 [Bentley 5], line 13) of the Cloud and the "fair eyed dew" (object 4 [Bentley 5], line 15) during their courtship.

component.illusobjdesc: A long, slender, willow-like tree arches over the title words and major pictorial motifs. This shape, with letters within, suggests the outline of a tombstone. It splits into several branches (perhaps bearing long, slender leaves) on the right.
A slender vine twines around the over-arching tree. Some of the vine's branches bear flowers and/or leaves.

Two open flowers and one bud bloom from the slender stems of a plant. These flowers may be the pasqueflower (anemone pulsatilla). They seem to be blown to the left by a gentle wind. The plant's large leaves bend to the ground. Three stems bearing spiky leaves, or the remnants of blossoms, or perhaps grain tassels also grow from the plant.
A vine or miniature tree arches over the figure seated and leaning against the B of the word "Book" (line 2).
Vines or tendrils grow from all four letters of the word "Book" (line 2).
Flame-like leaves spring from the first O of the word "Book" (line 2).

A flower, similar in shape to the much larger ones below, blooms from the K of the word "Book" (line 2). Two long stamens curve upward from the flower. Alternatively, a cluster of flame-like leaves sprouts from the K, and tiny flowers or buds on long stems curve upward from the cluster of leaves.
Slender vines twine about the letters of "Thel" (line 4). Two form empty spirals.
An upright plant sprouting from the bottom left serif of the K in “Book” (line 2), bears what may be leaves all along the stalk.

Thel, wearing a gown and holding a shepherd's crook, stands in a delicate contrapposto posture and looks upon the figures and flowers on the right. Her long hair curls over her shoulders; the hem of her gown curls about her feet and over the ground.

A gowned, apparently youthful, female hovers to the left of an open flower. She raises both arms above her head as a nude male embraces her waist. Her legs are spread apart as though she were striding to the left. Strands of her long hair can be seen left of her torso and right of her waist.
A nude, apparently youthful, man hovers to the left of an open flower and embraces a young woman around her waist. His legs are spread apart. He may have long hair (this is clearer in other copies).

A seated human figure, perhaps reading or writing in a book or tablet, sits and leans against the vertical of the letter B in the word "Book" (line 2). The figure's left leg dangles downward; the right leg appears to be crossed over the left (?) upper leg.
A human figure, probably male, stands within the second O of "Book" (line 3). He wears a hat and holds a shepherd's crook.
A young man, apparently nude, climbs the vertical of the letter T in "Thel" (line 5). He probably turns his face upward.
A gowned young woman stands on the foot of the left vertical of the letter H in "Thel" (line 5). She raises both arms above her head and appears to be facing up.
A gowned young woman stands on or hovers above the horizontal of the letter H in "Thel" (line 5). She raises both her arms above her head.
A very small figure stands just to the right of the second vertical of H in "Thel" (line 5).
A gowned or nude woman hovers above the letters E and L of "Thel" (line 4). Her legs extend to the left; her arms are raised horizontally.
A gowned angel with large wings sits on the horizontal, and leans against the vertical, of the letter L of "Thel" (line 4). The figure may be reading the book or tablet propped against his (?) knees.
A bird, wings extended, soars left of the word "of" in the title (line 4).
A bird, wings extended, soars right of the word "of" in the title (line 4).
Two curved strokes suggest a stylized bird, wings extended, flying below the shepherd’s crook in Thel’s hand.
Two curved strokes suggest a stylized bird, wings extended, flying below the letters H and E of “Thel” (line 4).
Some of the washes in the sky suggest clouds, possibly at sunrise or sunset.
Dark washes lower right hint at shadows.
The title words are integrated into the full-page design.

lg.l: THE BOOK of THEL
THE
BOOK
of
THEL
The Author & Printer Willm Blake. 1789.

objnote.p: Blake etched the number "1" upper right on the copperplate of object 2, but this number did not print in this copy.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Four human figures soar around the title-word "Thel": a nude man reaching toward a large eagle, a nude man holding a sword and shield, and a gowned woman holding a small child in her outstretched arms. Below, a fifth figure, a nude man, rests on a spiky leaf (or perhaps a tassel of grain) and looks up toward the child. Spiraling vines and stylized flowers, perhaps lilies, spring from several of the title letters. One or two trees or vines grow up the far left margin. Blake's coloring of this impression converts this text plate into a full-page design. The design does not represent any specific incident in the text, but the man with shield and spear may be one of the "thousand fighting men" referred to near the end of the poem (object 7 [Bentley 8], line 16).

component.illusobjdesc: Two vines, each terminating in what may be lily-like flowers, spring from the lower-left termination of the T of "Thel" (line 2).
A spiral vine descends from the H of "Thel" (line 2).
A vine spirals upwards from the L of "Thel" (line 2). It terminates in what may be a flower, perhaps a lily.
A spiky form that may be a stylized lily springs from the top-left corner of the H of "Thel" (line 2).
A small vine, branching at its lower end, hovers between the feet of the T and H in "Thel" (line 2). Alternatively, this might be a detached flower, possibly a lily.
A small vine extends horizontally beneath the E and L of "Thel" (line 2).
Two small vines extend horizontally above the T and the first vertical of the H in "Thel" (line 2).

A stalk curves up from near the beginning of line 4 and splits into a spiky leaf or tassel of grain (on which one of the figures rests) and a long slender leaf which arches over the figure’s head. (A vine or tree growing up the left-hand margin touches but does not support this stalk.)
A nude man hovers in the air, legs spread and with his right arm reaching (or pointing with one finger) toward an eagle.
A nude male hovers in the air. He holds a sword in his right hand; a shield is apparently strapped to his left arm.
A nude man reclines on a spiky leaf or tassel of grain. He props himself up with his right arm and turns his head upward.
A gowned woman hovers in the air. Her outstretched arms hold a young child.
An infant or young child hovers in the air, supported by a woman's outstretched arms. The child's legs are spread apart and its right arm may be extended toward the woman.
A large bird, probably an eagle, soars above the title-word "Thel" (line 2). Its prominent beak is open.
Blue, rose, and gold washes suggest clouds in the sky at sunrise or sunset.
The letters in the heading are integrated into the design.

lg.l: THEL

component.illusobjdesc: One or two trees or vines grow, intertwined, up the far left margin of the plate.
A rough terrain of stone or grayish earth runs along the lower margin of the plate.

lg.l: The daughters of Mne Seraphim led round their sunny flocks,
All but the youngest, she in paleness sought the secret air.
To fade away like morning beauty from her mortal day:
Down by the river of Adona her soft voice is heard:
And thus her gentle lamentation falls like morning dew.
O life of this our spring! why fades the lotus of the water?
Why fade these children of the spring? born but to smile & fall.
Ah! Thel is like a watry bow, and like a parting cloud.
Like a reflection in a glass, like shadows in the water.
Like dreams of infants, like a smile upon an infants face,
Like the doves voice, like transient day. like music in the air:
Ah! gentle may I lay me down, and gentle rest my head,

And gentle sleep the sleep of death, and gentle hear the voiceAt the end of the ninth word ("gentle") in line 16, Blake first wrote "e" and then wrote "y" over it before etching the copper plate. Both letters printed in proof copy a and possibly copy C; Blake then removed the "e" from the copper and printed the word as "gently" in copies K and R. He then reshaped the "y" into an "e" on the copper plate and printed the word as "gentle" in all other copies, sometimes strengthening the "e" in pen and ink.
Of him that walketh in the garden in the evening time.
The Lilly of the valley breathing in the humble grass
Answerd the lovely maid and said: I am a watry weed,
And I am very small, and love to dwell in lowly vales:
So weak, the gilded butterfly scarce perches on my head
Yet I am visited from heaven, and he that smiles on all.
Walks in the valley, and each morn over me spreads his hand
Saying, rejoice thou humble grass. thou new born lilly flower,
Thou gentle maid of silent valleys. and of modest brooks:
For thou shalt be clothed in light, and fed with morning manna;
Till summers heat melts thee beside the fountains and the springs
To flourish in eternal vales: then why should Thel complain,

objnote.p: The fragmentary "3" written in pencil upper right is not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Thel stands beneath the arching branches of a tree, perhaps a birch or willow. She bows slightly toward the personified Lilly who, with arms folded, bows more deeply toward Thel. Both females wear long gowns, ruffled along the hems. A vine climbs lazily about the tree trunk. The plant behind and to the right of the Lilly is probably a lily, perhaps the St. Bernard's lily. Washes in the text area suggest a sky with clouds at sunrise or sunset. A dark cloud frames Thel. Blake's coloring of this impression converts this text plate into a full-page design. The design illustrates the dialogue between Thel and the Lilly given in the text on this plate. The moment pictured may be their parting, when "the Lilly bowd her modest head" (line 18).

component.illusobjdesc: A tree with arching branches forms a canopy over the figures. It may be a birch or willow. Small leaves dangle from the smaller branches on the left.
A plant with spiky leaves grows between Thel and the tree. Vine-like stems bearing leaves or flowers curl in front of the tree.
A large lily plant, perhaps the St. Bernard's lily, blooms behind and to the right of the personified Lilly. It bears at least three flowering stems.
The coloring of the ground suggests grass along the lower margin of the plate.

Thel, wearing a long gown with a ruffled hem, stands with her arms at her side in a slightly bowed posture, facing to the left. Her long hair falls over her shoulders. Her feet (right foot forward) are bare.
The personified Lilly bows, with arms apparently folded, toward Thel. The hem of the Lilly's gown is elaborately ruffled. She appears to be hovering in front of the plant.
Washes suggest a sky at sunrise or sunset.
Some of the washes suggest the outlines of clouds in the sky, including areas around and within the text. There is also a large dark cloud behind Thel, framing her against the sky.

lg.l: Why should the mistress of the vales of Har, utter a sigh.
She ceasd & smild in tears, then sat down in her silver shrine.
Thel answerd, O thou little virgin of the peaceful valley.

Giving to those that cannot crave, the voiceless, the o'erfired.In copy N, the period at the end of the line is much higher, in relation to the letters in the line, than is customary. Perhaps this is actually the upper point of a colon or semicolon in which the lower element was not etched or did not print.
Thy breath doth nourish the innocent lamb. he smells thy milky garments,
He crops thy flowers. while thou sittest smiling in his face,
Wiping his mild and meekin mouth from all contagious taints.
Thy wine doth purify the golden honey, thy perfume,
Which thou dost scatter on every little blade of grass that springs,
Revives the milked cow, & tames the fire-breathing steed.
But Thel is like a faint cloud kindled at the rising sun;
I vanish from my pearly throne, and who shall find my place
Queen of the vales the Lilly answerd, ask the tender cloud,
And it shall tell thee why it glitters in the morning sky.
And why it scatters its bright beauty thro' the humid air.
Descend O little cloud & hover before the eyes of Thel,
The Cloud descended. and the Lilly bowd her modest head:
And went to mind her numerous charge among the verdant grass.

objnote.p: The number "4" in pencil at top right is not by Blake. Much of the plate is spotted with gray-brown stains.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The printed etching border along the left margin suggests a cliff. Yellow wash below the text hints at a sky at sunrise or sunset. The mottled brown or gray patches are stains, not motifs.

component.illusobjdesc: The printed etching border along the left margin suggests a cliff.
Yellow wash below the texts hints at a sky at sunrise or sunset.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two vines, one bearing lily-like flowers, spring from the beginning of the first line of verse (line 2).

component.illusobjdesc: Two vines, one bearing lily-like flowers, spring from the beginning of the first line of verse (line 2).

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine or two branches grow from the end of the last line of verse (line 32).

component.illusobjdesc: A vine or two branches, the lower one perhaps with leaves, grow from the end of the last line of verse (line 32).

l.note: The etched number "3" is very lightly printed.

lg.l: O little Cloud. the virgin said, I charge thee tell to me.
Why thou complainest not when in one hour thou fade away;
Then we shall seek thee but not find; ah Thel is like to thee.
I pass away. yet I complain, and no one hears my voice.
The Cloud then shewd his golden head & his bright form emerg'd.
Hovering and glittering on the air before the face of Thel.
O virgin know'st thou not: our steeds drink of the golden springs
Where Luvah doth renew his horses: look'st thou on my youth,
And fearest thou because I vanish and am seen no more.
Nothing remains; O maid I tell thee. when I pass away,
It is to tenfold life, to love, to peace, and raptures holy:
Unseen descending, weigh my light wings upon balmy flowers:
And court the fair eyed dew. to take me to her shining tent;

The weeping virgin, trembling kneels before the risen sun.In copy N, there is a mark below the final period (and below the line of text) which might convert the final period into a very low-hanging colon or semicolon.
Till we arise link'd in a golden band, and never part;
But walk united, bearing food to all our tender flowers.
Dost thou O little Cloud? I fear that I am not like thee;
For I walk through the vales of Har, and smell the sweetest flowers:
But I feed not the little flowers: I hear the warbling birds,
But I feed not the warbling birds, they fly and seek their food:
But Thel delights in these no more because I fade away,
And all shall say, without a use this shining woman liv'd,
Or did she only live. to be at death the food of worms.
The Cloud reclind upon his airy throne and answer'd thus.
Then if thou art the food of worms. O virgin of the skies,
How great thy use. how great thy blessing; every thing that lives,
Lives not alone. nor for itself; fear not and I will call
The weak worm from its lowly bed, and thou shalt hear its voice
Come forth worm of the silent valley, to thy pensive queen.
The helpless worm arose, and sat upon the Lillys leaf,
And the bright Cloud saild on, to find his partner in the vale.

objnote.p: The number "5" in pencil at top right is not by Blake. The number "4," etched upper right on the copperplate, is not legible in this copy.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Thel stands center right, accompanied by the personified Cloud and Worm. Her arms, raised horizontally, imitate the gesture of the cloud, a nude male (except for a slip of drapery) hovering in the air. The hem of Thel's gown and the posture of the personified Cloud suggest a wind blowing from right to left. However, the position of these characters' long hair suggests a breeze in the opposite direction. The Worm, portrayed as an infant, rests in a bed formed by a lily plant. Several flowers on a single stem are pictured just to the left of the infant Worm. A large tree and spiraling vine dominate the right margin. The design would seem to illustrate the last two lines of verse on the previous plate and the first line of verse on this plate: "The helpless worm arose, and sat upon the Lillys leaf, / and the bright Cloud saild on, to find his partner in the vale. / . . . Then Thel astonish'd view'd the Worm upon its dewy bed" (object 4, lines 32-33; object 5, line 2).

component.illusobjdesc: The trunk of a tree, perhaps a birch, is pictured along the right margin. A short limb divides into two branches.
A vine bearing a single leaf spirals upward in front of and to the left of the tree.
A large plant with spiky leaves, possibly a St. Bernard's lily, forms a bed for the infant Worm. A long vine-like tendril trails to the left. A sprig of flowers appears left of the Worm.
A few spiky lines indicate grass or a small plant to the left of the tree.
A few wavy lines and the green coloring indicate grass covering the ground along the lower margin of the design.

Thel stands with arms raised horizontally, as if imitating the Cloud's gestures, and looks down at the personified Worm. The hem of her gown flutters to the left, as though blown by a breeze, but her long hair seems blown to the right. She may be striding away from the viewer and to the left. Her feet, left foot forward, are bare.

The personified Cloud hovers in the air, his arms raised horizontally and his legs apart, the left bent at the knee. He is basically nude, but a flag-like piece of drapery trails behind him. His long hair floats to the right. His body faces forward, but his head is turned back slightly to the right.

The personified Worm, a nude infant, lies among the leaves and blossoms of a lily plant. (The Worm may be male, judging by what may be male genitalia in the illustration on the following plate, but in the text the Worm is not "he" but "it," as in the first line of verse on this plate.) It may be looking up and to the right, towards Thel.

At least one large cloud is outlined, with lighter washes extending the outline up around the personified Cloud. This cloud fades up into white and blue, but the underside of this cloud is dark. Below its dark underside, to the right of Thel's legs, futher outlining may indicate either a lighter cloud or a lighter extension of the same cloud.

The hem of Thel's gown and the posture of the personified Cloud suggest a wind blowing from right to left. However, the position of these characters' long hair suggests a breeze in the opposite direction.
Blue washes top right suggest sky, while washes to the bottom and right in the design suggest a sunrise or sunset.

lg.l: Then Thel astonish'd view'd the Worm upon its dewy bed.
Art thou a Worm? image of weakness. art thou but a Worm?
I see thee like an infant wrapped in the Lillys leaf:
Ah weep not little voice, thou can'st not speak, but thou can'st weep;
Is this a Worm? I see thee lay helpless & naked: weeping,
And none to answer. none to cherish thee with mothers smiles.
The Clod of Clay heard the Worms voice, & raisd her pitying head:
She bowd over the weeping infant. and her life exhal'd
In milky fondness. then on Thel she fix'd her humble eyes.
O beauty of the vales of Har. we live not for ourselves.
Thou seest me the meanest thing, and so I am indeed;
My bosom of itself is cold. and of itself is dark,

illustration.illusobjdesc: Thel squats on the ground, arms folded, and looks at the personified Worm and Clod (or "matron Clay" [line 15]). Her long hair cascades over her shoulders; the hem of her long gown billows around her. The infant Worm extends both arms and looks at the Clod, a young, nude woman lying on the ground. She may be reaching for her offspring. Right of Thel is a large plant with spiky leaves and two blossoms, one of which arches over Thel's head. Left of Thel is another plant with similar leaves but no blossoms. Blake has added water on the left and in the foreground, suggesting a river or lake. Given this configuration, the figures may be on an island or peninsula. At the bottom left, a small plant bearing leaves or flowers appears to grow in soil across the water from the central figures. Washes beneath and on all sides of the text may indicate clouds. Blake's coloring of this impression converts this text plate into a full-page design. The design may in part illustrate lines on the previous plate: "The Clod of Clay heard the Worms voice, & raisd her pitying head; / She bow'd over the weeping infant..." (plate 5, lines 9-10).

component.illusobjdesc: A large plant with spiky leaves grows on the right. One of its two flowers arches above Thel's head. Long stamens dangle from the blossom on the right; the blossom on the left is less open and may be only a bud. The plant may be a combination of the flowers of the Meadia or dodecatheon, the golden amaryllis, and the leaves of the St. Bernard's lily.
A large plant with spiky leaves rises to the left of Thel. This may be the colorless monotropa or corpse-plant.
Two stems grow just left of Thel's waist. Each terminates in a small, lily-like flower.

A sprig of flowers, perhaps the St. Bernard's lily, arches to the right of the Worm's waist. The flowers are more distinct in other copies; in this copy, only the curved stem is colored to stand out, suggesting a blade of grass.
At the bottom left, a small plant bearing leaves or flowers appears to grow in the ground across the water from the central figures.
Spiky lines in the lower right corner and coloring along the lower margin suggest grass growing on the ground across the water from the central figures.

Thel squats on the ground, her arms folded over her chest and knees in a contracted position. Her long hair falls over her shoulders; the hem of her long gown cascades around her. She looks down at the personified Clod and Worm with head bowed.

The nude, infant Worm lies on the ground with legs crossed and arms extended at an angle of 135 degrees. (The Worm may be male, judging by what may be male genitalia in the illustration, but in the text the Worm is not "he" but "it," as in line 12 on this plate.) Its head is turned toward the Clod.
The personified Clod or "matron Clay" (line 16) lies on the ground. She is a nude young woman with long hair. Her right arm extends under the infant Worm, perhaps reaching for him.
A small river runs near the left and lower margins. Alternatively, this water may be part of a small lake.
Because of the water on the left and in the foreground, the figures may be sitting on an island or peninsula.

Washes divide the background into a warm yellow-orange mass (gathered lower left and sweeping up along the left and top margins), and a dark blue mass (gathered lower right and fading upward). They may indicate a light cloud against a dark sky, a dark cloud against a light sky, or two clouds. The coloring may indicate night transitioning to sunrise or sunset transitioning to night. Dark coloring lower right, below and right of the large flowering plant, suggests shadows.

l.note: The etched number "5" is only minimally legible in this copy.

lg.l: But he that loves the lowly, pours his oil upon my head,
And kisses me, and binds his nuptial bands around my breast.
And says; Thou mother of my children, I have loved thee.
And I have given thee a crown that none can take away:
But how this is sweet maid, I know not, and I cannot know.
I ponder, and I cannot ponder; yet I live and love.
The daughter of beauty wip'd her pitying tears with her white veil,
And said. Alas! I knew not this. and therefore did I weep:
That God would love a Worm I knew, and punish the evil foot
That wilful, bruis'd its helpless form: but that he cherish'd it
With milk and oil. I never knew; and therefore did I weep.
And I complaind in the mild air, because I fade away.
And lay me down in thy cold bed. and leave my shining lot.
Queen of the vales, the matron Clay answerd; I heard thy sighs.
And all thy moans flew o'er my roof. but I have call'd them down:
Wilt thou O Queen enter my house, 'tis given thee to enter.
And to return; fear nothing. enter with thy virgin feet.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Three nude children ride on the back of a snake. The front-most child, apparently a girl, holds a rein in her left hand that extends to the snake's open mouth. His forked tongue is extended. Beneath the snake are a variety of vegetative forms, including leaves and roots. "The End" (line 27) is written within a hollow formed by the ground and vegetation. Washes in the text area suggest sky or clouds. Blake's coloring of this impression converts this text plate into a full-page design. The design bears no direct relationship with any images or events in the text.

component.illusobjdesc: Long, rounded forms on the horizon left of the snake, as well as spiky lines and the coloring in the lower margin suggest either leaves, grass and perhaps small plants on the ground, or stone and rocks.
Curved and pointed forms left of "The End" (line 28) may be leaves.
One large leaf rests on the ground right of "The End" (line 28). This may be an oak leaf.
A nude young girl with long hair rides the snake's back. She holds a rein in her left hand and faces to the left.

A nude child or infant, probably male, rides on the snake's back. His legs are spread apart. He reaches back with his left arm to grasp the left hand of the infant behind him. A few lines suggest short curly hair.
A nude infant rides the snake's back nearest the tail. He(?) faces left and reaches up with his left arm to grasp the hand of the child to the left.
A snake carries three children on his back. His mouth is open, forked tongue extended. His tail spirals into three loops.
Some of the washes in the text area may indicate sky or clouds illuminated by a sunrise or sunset.
The words "The End" (line 28) appear within a hollow formed by the ground and vegetation.

lg.l: The End

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine or branch with a few leaves curves above the first two words of the text (line 4). A few lines top right may indicate another sprig of vegetation.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine or branch with a few leaves curves above the first two words of the text of the poem (line 4).

illustration.illusobjdesc: A curved, horizontal line right of line 19 of the text suggests a vine or branch. To the right is a bird in flight. Further to the right are a few lines and a wispy form that may represent clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine or branch extends horizontally right of line 19 of the text.
A bird flies upward right of line 19 of the text.
A few lines and a wispy form may represent clouds right line 19 of the text.

l.note: The etched number "6" is only minimally legible in this copy.

lg.l: The eternal gates terrific porter lifted the northern bar:
Thel enter'd in & saw the secrets of the land unknown;
She saw the couches of the dead, & where the fibrous roots
Of every heart on earth infixes deep its restless twists:
A land of sorrows & of tears where never smile was seen.
She wanderd in the land of clouds thro' valleys dark, listning
Dolours & lamentations: waiting oft beside a dewy grave
She stood in silence. listning to the voices of the ground,
Till to her own grave plot she came, & there she sat down.
And heard this voice of sorrow breathed from the hollow pit -
Why cannot the Ear be closed to its own destruction?
Or the glistning Eye to the poison of a smile!
Why are Eyelids stord with arrows ready drawn,
Where a thousand fighting men in ambush lie?
Or an Eye of gifts & graces. show'ring fruits & coined
gold!
Why a Tongue impress'd with honey from every wind?
Why an Ear, a whirlpool fierce to draw creations in?
Why a Nostril wide inhaling terror trembling & affright.
Why a tender curb upon the youthful burning boy!
Why a little curtain of flesh on the bed of our desire?
The Virgin started from her seat, & with a shriek:
Fled back unhinderd till she came into the vales of
Har.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Washes fade from light blue at top left to a darker and greyer blue at bottom, and to white on the right, suggesting a sky darker at the horizon, with a cloud or clouds to the right.

component.illusobjdesc: Washes fade from light blue at top left to a darker and greyer blue at bottom, and to white on the right, suggesting a sky darker at the horizon, with a cloud or clouds to the right.

lg.l: Does the Eagle know what is in the pit?
Or wilt thou go ask the Mole:
Can Wisdom be put in a silver rod?
Or Love in a golden bowl?
